title: Samsung, suppliers sink on smartphone woes but Asia stocks gain

text:
Samsung, suppliers sink on smartphone woes but Asia stocks gain
Tech supplier shares sank in Asia Thursday as South Korean giant Samsung Electronics posted a huge fall in profit, a day after rival Apple recorded its weakest ever rise in iPhone sales.
The 40 percent fall in Samsung's net profit and Apple's report fuelled fears about the saturated smartphone market and the impact on smaller firms that rely on their ongoing popularity.
Adding to the concerns, Samsung said it expected this year to throw up continued challenges, which was in line with a warning that it saw sales of its popular handheld device falling for the first time this quarter. Apple dived 6.5 percent in US trade.
Asian tech supplier share falls came despite a broad pick-up across regional stock markets ©Wang Zhao (AFP/File)
Samsung sank more than two percent in the morning in Seoul. Among regional suppliers, Tokyo-listed Alps Electric -- which Wednesday cut its profit forecast because of weak smartphone sales -- plunged almost 16 percent. Japan Display lost almost five percent and TDK almost seven percent.
LG Display in Seoul was 3.7 percent off.
The losses came despite a broad pick-up across regional stock markets, despite losses on Wall Street after the Federal Reserve left open the door to another interest rate hike.
After concluding its first meeting since lifting rates in December, the US central bank kept rates unchanged and said growth in the world's number one economy slowed late last year and was concerned about ongoing global weaknesses.
- Focus on BoJ meeting -
However, despite the turmoil that has wracked world markets so far in 2016, policymakers added that they expected inflation -- softened by falling oil prices -- would rise toward its 2.0 percent target in the medium term. The comment was seen as keeping the Fed's option open for another hike in March.
"With investor sentiment quite poor and fixated on the negatives, they'll likely latch onto the Fed's focus over global risks," Mitsushige Akino, an executive officer at Ichiyoshi Asset Management, told Bloomberg News.
"However, rather than a hawkish statement, I think we got one that was market friendly. And that should impact stocks over the longer run."
By lunch Tokyo's Nikkei index was up 0.2 percent, while Hong Kong gained 0.5 percent and Sydney 0.7 percent. Seoul was slightly lower, with Samsung acting as a drag. Shanghai slipped 0.4 percent, with ongoing worries about the domestic economy continuing to play on investors' minds.
Next up is the Bank of Japan's policy meeting, which concludes Friday. While expectations are that it will not move just yet, its statement will be pored over for an idea about policymakers' thinking as Japan's economy stumbles and local stock markets are jostled by the global rout.
On oil markets, both global contracts turned lower with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate down 0.9 percent and Brent 0.8 percent off.
They posted gains Wednesday, even after a report showed US stockpiles surged last week. Analysts said the rally was in reaction to the fact the rise was not as big as expected.
